--- title: "Probability Examples" number-sections: true image: "/images/biostats.jpg" date: "2024-12-20" format: html: fig-align: center page-layout: article toc: true toc-depth: 5 toc-expand: true lightbox: false filters: - highlight-text crossref: custom: - kind: float reference-prefix: "Example M.10." key: tabset space-before-numbering: false editor_options: chunk_output_type: console --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Examples of probability and counting problems ::: panel-tabset ## Example C.5.1 {{< iconify ic:round-menu-book size=21px >}} A fruit packaging company is preparing “Mixed Fruit Boxes” for customers. Each box contains $15$ pieces of fruit, which can be selected from $5$ different types of fruit: apples, bananas, oranges, mangoes, and kiwis. The packers can include any combination of these fruits in each box. [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} How many possible combinations are there for the fruit boxes? [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} What is the probability that the customer receives a box that contains at least one fruit from each type? **Answers** [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} In the first question, we want to fill $15$ slots in the box with fruits from $5$ different types: - Fruits can be repeated and the order does not matter, so we are dealing with a **combination with replacement problem**: - Let the number of fruit types be $n = 5$ and the number of fruits to be packed is $m = 15$. - The number of possible combinations is given as: $$ \binom{n + m - 1}{m} = \binom{5 + 15 - 1}{15} = \binom{19}{15} = 3,876 $$ [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} In the second question, we want to find in how many ways the boxes contain at least one fruit from each type: - To ensure that each type of fruit is included in the box, we need to assign one fruit from each type to a slot in the box. - This means that we use $5$ slots leaving $10$ slots to be filled with any fruit combination. - This is also a **combination with replacement problem** but now $n = 5$ and $m = 10$: - This is is given as: $$ \binom{5+10-1}{10} = \dbinom{14}{10} = 1,001 $$ - So, the probability that a random box contains at least one fruit from each type is: $$ \frac{1001}{3876} = 0.258 $$ ## Example C.5.2 {{< iconify ic:round-menu-book size=21px >}} The Olympic Games final of the $100$ m sprint consists of $8$ runners. How many combinations for the top $3$ finishers exist when: [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} Order matters ? [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} Order does not matter? **Answers** [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} Order matters: - We want to find the number of arrangements for the top $3$ finishers from $8$ runners. - This is a **permutation problem** where order matters but without replacement because a runner cannot finish in more than one position. - The number of permutations is given as: $$ _8P_3 = \frac{8!}{(8-3)!} = \frac{8!}{5!} = 336 $$ [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} Order does not matter: - When order does not matter, we are dealing with a **combination problem** and again without replacement. - The number of combinations is given as: $$ _8C_3 = \frac{8!}{3! \cdot\ (8-3)!} = \frac{8!}{3!\cdot\ 5!} = 56 $$ ## Example C.5.3 {{< iconify ic:round-menu-book size=21px >}} Given three pairwise disjoint and exhaustive events $A$, $B$, and $C$. $$ P(A) = 0.1, \quad P(B) = 0.3 $$ **Calculate**: [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} $P(B')$ [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} $P(C)$ [{{< iconify bi:3-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} $P(A \cup B)$ [{{< iconify bi:4-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} $P(A \cap B)$ [{{< iconify bi:5-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} $P(C \setminus C)$ **Answers**: [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} $P(B') = 1 - P(B) = 1- 0.3 = 0.7$ [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} The events are exhaustive and pairwise disjoint, so: - $P(A \cup B \cup C) = P(A) + P(B) + P(C) = 1$ - $P(C) = 1 - P(A) - P(B) = 1 - 0.1 - 0.3 = 0.6$ [{{< iconify bi:3-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} The events are disjoint, so - $P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) = 0.1 + 0.3 = 0.4$ [{{< iconify bi:4-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} The events are disjoint, so: - $P(A \cap B) = 0$ [{{< iconify bi:5-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} $P(C \setminus C) = 0$ ## [Exercise C.5.1 {{< iconify fluent:chat-bubbles-question-20-filled size=21px >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} A restaurant surveyed its customers for complaints about food quality and service quality. The restaurant found that: $30\%$ of customers complain about food quality, $19\%$ of customers complain about service quality, and $12\%$ of customers complain about both food and service. If a customer is randomly selected, what is the probability that this customer: [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} Complains about at least one category? - The answer is [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} Complains only about food quality, not service? - The answer is [{{< iconify bi:3-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} Does not complain about either category? - The answer is [{{< iconify bi:4-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} Complains about only one category? - The answer is ## Example C.5.4 {{< iconify ic:round-menu-book size=21px >}} You have a set of $4$ red, $5$ orange, and $2$ blue balls. [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} How many different arrangements of the balls can be made? **Answers**: [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} There are $3$ distinct groups of balls but the balls within each group are identical. - To find the distinct arrangements, we are dealing with a **permutation** of multiple distinguishable groups with indistinguishable objects. - The number of arrangements is given as: $$ \frac{11!}{4! \cdot\ 5! \cdot\ 2!} = 6,930 $$ ## Example C.5.5 {{< iconify ic:round-menu-book size=21px >}} A school has $7$ teachers, each is preassigned $2$ classrooms by the principal. The teachers are asked to select $2$ classrooms for the upcoming school year. What is the probability that a specific teacher: [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} Selects both of their preassigned classrooms? [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} Selects none of their preassigned classrooms? **Answer** [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} Each teacher can choose $2$ classrooms from $14$ available classrooms: - This is a **combination without replacement** problem, where the order does not matter. - The total number of ways to select $2$ classrooms from $14$ is: $$ _{14}C_2 = \binom{14}{2} = \frac{14!}{2! \cdot\ 12!} = 91 $$ - There is only $1$ way to select both preassigned classrooms, so its probability is: $$ \frac{1}{91} = 0.011 $$ [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: dodgerblue"} When a teacher selects none of the preassigned classrooms, this means selecting $2$ classrooms from the remaining $12$ non-preassigned classrooms: - The number of ways to select $2$ classrooms from $12$ is: $$ _{12}C_2 = \binom{12}{2} = \frac{12!}{2! \cdot\ 10!} = 66 $$ - So, the probability that a teacher selects none of the preassigned classrooms is: $$ \frac{66}{91} = 0.725 $$ ## [Exercise C.5.2 {{< iconify fluent:chat-bubbles-question-20-filled size=21px >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} [{{< iconify bi:1-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} How many ways are there to arrange $6$ different antibiotic packages on a shelf? - The answer is [{{< iconify bi:2-circle-fill size=20px fill=blue >}}]{style="color: #ba181b"} In how many ways can $3$ antibiotic packages be chosen from $6$ packages? - The answer is :::
